DOCNAME: MELERO ECHAURI AND OSTIZ MELERO v. SPAIN
JUDGES: Alvina Gyulumyan;Corneliu Bîrsan;Egbert Myjer;Ján Šikuta;Josep Casadevall;Luis López Guerra;Nona Tsotsoria
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants , PERSON and PERSON , are NORP nationals who were born in GPE ( GPE ) in DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE . They are mother and daughter and work as associate lawyers in their law firm in GPE . They are represented before ORG by PERSON , the first applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE , as the result of disciplinary and criminal proceedings brought by GPE civil judge no . CARDINAL against the first applicant for defamation , the applicant was admonished by ORG for a minor infraction , of lack of respect to a judge and a fellow lawyer . In fact , the applicant , acting in her capacity as counsel in separation proceedings , had submitted a brief in which she had accused the judge in the case of general malfeasance in favouring a lawyer with whom the judge appeared to be friendly , to the detriment of the rights to defence and to a fair hearing of her clients and of other ORG clients .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant requested the GPE judge responsible for the allocation of cases ( “ the GPE judge ” ) to have the case allocation rules of the courts of GPE altered so as to guarantee her clients the right to defence and to a fair hearing . In her view , these rights would be seriously jeopardised if her cases and those of her daughter were allocated to GPE civil judge no . CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE judge refused the applicant ’s request and invited her to make use , whenever she found it appropriate , of a request for withdrawal . This decision was upheld by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , on the occasion of a civil action against CARDINAL of her clients , the first applicant submitted a request for withdrawal of GPE civil judge no . CARDINAL . That request was refused by the judge on DATE on the ground that , pursuant to LAW , in civil , social and adversarial administrative proceedings only the parties and the public prosecutor had standing to request that a judge withdraw from a case .

CARDINAL . The first applicant introduced an appeal against that decision before the same civil judge no . CARDINAL , arguing that the fact that that judge had introduced criminal and disciplinary proceedings against her in the past disqualified the judge from deciding in cases in which the first applicant acted as counsel , and that it was a legal absurdity to request that her clients submit a request for withdrawal since , according to the legislation in force , the request would not be successful , in so far as no enmity could be said to exist , in principle , between the judge and her clients . The appeal was orally dismissed on DATE , the judge insisting that if there were to be such a request it could only be submitted by the applicant ’s client .
CARDINAL . The applicant introduced an amparo appeal that was declared inadmissible on DATE by ORG on the ground that the applicant lacked standing . That decision was served on DATE .
CARDINAL . DATE LAW reads as follows :

“ CARDINAL . Everyone has the right to obtain the effective protection of judges and the courts in the exercise of his or her legitimate rights and interests , and in no case may he or she go undefended .

CARDINAL . Likewise , everyone has the right of access to the ordinary courts as predetermined by law ; to the defence and assistance of a lawyer ; to be informed of the charges brought against them ; to a public trial without undue delays and with full guarantees ; to the use of evidence appropriate to their defence ; not to make self - incriminating statements ; not to declare themselves guilty ; and to be presumed innocent . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of Organic Law DATE , on the ORG identifies those who have standing to request the withdrawal of a judge . It reads as follows :
“ The withdrawal of a judge can only be requested :

CARDINAL . In civil , social and adversarial administrative proceedings by the parties ; the public prosecutor shall have also standing to request the withdrawal of a judge in those cases in which , by the character of the rights in dispute , he could or should intervene ” .
Article CARDINAL of the Organic Law on the ORG enumerates the reasons for abstention and withdrawal of judges . The relevant part of LAW of this case reads as follows :
“ Grounds for abstention and , if appropriate , for withdrawal are ...
CARDINAL . A close friendship with or a manifest enmity towards any of the parties ... ”
